The pawn at d4 isn't going anywhere immediately. White will castle and then be free to mingle about.
The pawn at d4 isn't going anywhere immediately. White will castle and then be free to mingle about.
This position is different than the Steinitz game where Black has a pawn on e4. White plays b4 anyway sacrificing a second pawn for freedom on the dance floor.

White down -2, but with good mobility available for all minor pieces. Castled and have e1 open for the rook, queen poised on d file. Blacks developed pieces aren't under any immediate threat per se, but at the same time they do not have good squares to move onto.

8. Qe7? Not what I expected and not generally thought to be sound practice. I heard somewhere..."try not to place your queen in front of your king...."______ Well, I was anticipating Nf6 or d6.

Naturally, the rook Whites rook tucks in on the e file exerting pressure on Blacks queen. White follows 9....d6 ( which I think is a little late) with 10. Nd5! And black has to be careful now with the threat of Nc3+! Forks are good, right? At this point black decides to log out and take a break.

White wants to eliminate the Black knight from it's defensive post and remove the option of any future thoughts on playing Nc2.
Here it becomes clear that Black is not interesting in trading. Perhaps, 13....dxBc4 and create space for movement. Doesn't matter now.

The knight on f7 is placed too well to bother picking off the rook on h7. The queen moves forward to get a better angle. !7.... Rh7 accomplishes nothing.
